name: Elliot
title: Diary Entry
contentHtml:
A couple of days on and I drew supply run duty. Proper one this time, outside the walls and into town. Skipton again, but deeper. Five of us packed into a small van that’s seen better decades. A strange mix of metal, leather, and layered cloth armour between us, like history got drunk and dressed us in the dark.

I kept my shortbow in hand the whole drive. Quiver strapped tight at my hip. This wasn’t wall work. No longbows, no arcs and ranges and patience. Streets are close, messy. You need something quick. A hammer hung on my other hip, solid and comforting in the way only blunt tools are.

We split up near the high street, pairs peeling off toward pharmacies and hardware shops. I headed straight for the camping supply store I’d circled on the map days ago. I’d studied those maps until the folds went soft and the streets felt memorised.

Inside, the first thing I did was sit down.

I kicked off my ruined trainers and swapped them for a proper pair of hiking boots from the shelf. Thick soles. Good ankle support. I laced them tight and stood, stamping once. Immediate improvement. Feet matter more than almost anything now.

Then I stripped the place for all it was worth.

Expedition gear first. Heavy-duty packs, spare straps, dry bags, carabiners, cord. Anything designed to survive mountains could survive this.

I grabbed the largest hiking rucksack I could find, the kind meant to carry someone’s entire bad decision across a continent. Dehydrated rations followed, swept into the bag by the armful. Calories without fuss.

I moved on to the tents and stopped being gentle. I ripped bags open, pulling out fiberglass poles and snapping them down to workable lengths. Perfect stock for crossbow bolts once cut and fletched. Improvised, sure, but straight and strong. I cleared the shelves of water filtration tablets. Every single one. Clean water is time.

I was slinging the loaded rucksack onto my shoulder when I heard it.

A low moan, wet and unfinished, drifting from behind the till. Staff area.

I dropped instantly, sliding in behind a crate of folded camp chairs. The rucksack hit the floor softly beside me. I drew an arrow, breath slow, and leaned just enough to peer around the edge.

A figure on the floor. Legs destroyed, smashed beyond use by whoever looted the place before me. Left there. Still moving. Still suffering.

I muttered, barely audible, “Lazy buggers. Finish the job.”

The arrow took it clean through the skull.

Silence again.

I didn’t waste time after that. I hauled the rucksack back up, swept a handful of pocket knives from the display case by the door, and ran. Out into the street, scanning windows and alleys as I made for the van.

We didn’t say much on the drive back.

But my feet didn’t hurt.
And the haul was good

name: Nathan
title: Taxi Ride
contentHtml:
I leaned out of the side window of a battered looking old taxi. That had been Anna's idea - great turning circle, regularly maintained to a high standard, and great fuel capacity. It wasn't mine officially, of course, and it wouldn't be giving lifts to the public anytime soon: behind the plastic screen, there was barely room to move between the piles and piles of supplies. Tins of food and soup, animal feed, seeds, soil, fencing, and a pile of tools which would have been considered expensive until a couple of weeks ago, but now would be considered priceless. B&Q was a risky stop, and I suspected pickings would be slim, but it turned out that looters seemed reluctant to check the back rooms of the shops they were ransacking. 

Given the circumstances, maybe that was sensible.

The view before me was hard to comprehend.
The M1 was considered a hellscape by most people on a normal day, but now? An overturned lorry blocked the northbound carriageway, and abandoned vehicles dotted the landscape, both on and off the road. People had clearly tried to swerve to avoid it, but the barriers and the trees had proved too much, and there was no way through.
Well, if you were on the left side of the road, that is.

"This is definitely a bit risky," I said, creeping up the hard shoulder on the right side of the road. Even a week ago, horns would be blaring and the police would already be on their way, but now traffic was sparse, and passed by wide, comparatively slowly. Nobody wanted to die in a car crash in the apocalypse; there's far more exciting ways to die than that these days. There were abandoned cars on pretty much every road occasionally, with little sign of occupancy.

Guess they got hungry.

"I might get a ticket or something," I continued, swerving around an ambulance with its wheels pointed to the sky. The siren continued to blare, a morbid reminder that things were not as they once were. "I can see why people told me to avoid the motorways."
Nobody replied, of course. Not even an eye roll. I glanced to my left, where Pringle sat perched on the passenger seat, looking at me intently. I sighed, and gave her a little scratch under her chin. She licked my hand back.

Anna was in Ibiza. Trust her to pick the weekend before the end of the world to fly out with the girls! No danger for them yet, last I’d heard. Phone signal’s been pretty patchy though, and I haven’t heard anything for a couple of days.

A parking bay slipped by on the right, and I hit the brakes, moving even slower. The exit was coming up soon, and trying to read the signs across the central reservation with cars zooming across you was a recipe for missing your exit. With a sharp U-turn, I let out a sigh of relief, wheels rolling up the exit ramp.

“Remind me to never do that again,” I said, glancing at the signs. Huddersfield. My phone buzzed as I approached civilisation, moving ever closer to Skipton. It’s hard to believe that infrastructure collapsed so quickly that the journey had taken nearly three days.

I parked up at a petrol station, but kept the doors locked and the engine running. No point in trying to get fuel any more. The windows of the attached store were shattered, and the sign told me that the price had hit fifteen pounds a litre before they had finally given up. Unbelievable.

I took a quick sip of water, and stole a look at my phone. Best to make use of the signal while I had it.
“TRUMP TAKES GREENLAND, BUT AT WHAT COST?!” read the headline, the picture showing a burning White House. I rolled my eyes, flicking the notification away before tapping on discord, typing out a few words quickly. My eyes kept darting to the windows, keeping an eye out for any movement.

“Still alive” I typed, pausing as a pigeon landed on the petrol dispenser, beady eyes seeming to stare directly at me. Pringle growled. Something in my gut churned.
I glanced back at my phone, tapping out a few more characters.

“Still alive. Watch out for birds. I’ll be there by nightfall.”

I read the words, and then reread them. Am I being paranoid?
A second pigeon landed next to the first, claws gripping the handle of the diesel dispenser. Pringle let out a strange whine-bark, and my spine tingled. I hit send, and without waiting for a response I hit the gas.

Tyres squealed as the taxi lurched back onto the road.
The birds followed.

name: Elliot
title: PM entry
contentHtml:
The day wound down without anything catching fire that wasn’t meant to, which feels like success. As the light faded and watch shifts changed, I retreated to one of the side rooms off the barracks with a mug of something pretending to be tea and my most important duty of the evening.

Game prep.

It feels ridiculous admitting it, even in here. But D&D has become our guilt pleasure, our pressure valve. A few hours where the walls are just scenery and danger is measured in dice, not teeth. In a place built for vigilance, it’s the closest thing we have to rest.

No D&D Beyond, no tablets, no tidy digital indexes. Just weight. I spread the tomes of knowledge out across the table, pages soft with age and fingerprints, margins packed with notes from people who never thought they’d be doing this by candlelight in a castle. I ran my fingers over spell lists and monster entries like they might rearrange themselves into something easier.

I sketched until my hand cramped. An intricate mansion, all sharp angles and secret corridors, every room carefully planned. In the basement, I made sure the vault was obvious. Too obvious. Heavy door, ridiculous locks, the kind of thing that practically screams distraction. Let them argue about it. Let them overthink.

Then I pulled out a children’s riddle book I’d scavenged days ago, the cover half chewed and the pages stained with something sticky. I flipped through until I found the right one and wove it into the puzzle, childish on the surface, cruel underneath. The best kind.

I leaned back, listening to the muffled sounds of the castle settling around me. Boots on stone. A laugh cut short. Wind through canvas.

“This should take them plenty of time,” I muttered to myself, smiling despite everything.

If the world is going to end, it can wait until after initiative is rolled.

name: Eve
title: The apocalypse is great!
contentHtml:
I can spend all day spinning wool or carding fibers and no one yells at me for waisting the day doing stupid things. 

Fuck you industrial revolution you wrecked the simple way of life. Its not easy, have to be up to feed the animals and then it's all day sewing or spinning or weaving. I'm so glad I brought my hand crank machine (ok industrial revolution you where right in some places) 

They keep saying I will get fed up with it at somepoint but sewing cloths and bags and useful things has never been so rewarding. If I want a break I just hop on a scout mission to go "shopping for fabric" we have even found two COUNT EM two treddel machines aswell. Its great. Being part of a little team of seamstress is great we just sit and knit and sew and crochet and natter and gossip and tell storys.

The only down side. Having to teach people how to thread a needed makes me want to murder.

Other than that life is sweet here. Fuck social this was a longtime coming and we are better for it.

name: Elliot
title: Training day
contentHtml:
It’s been a few days now, long enough for the castle to stop feeling like borrowed space and start feeling like somewhere I might actually wake up tomorrow. I slid out of my bunk before the bell, careful not to kick the frame. The barracks were already alive in that quiet, purposeful way. People moving without talking, like noise itself might cost us something.

Stone under boots, breath fogging faintly, I headed for the storage hall. The place smells of dust, oil, and old grain. I picked up the day’s supply request forms from the table near the door. Paper everywhere, clipped, folded, smudged. Requests for bandages, lamp oil, dried food, bolts for crossbows. The kind of lists that make chaos look manageable. I tucked them under my arm and told myself that meant I was useful.

On the way out, I glanced up at the walls. An archer stood watch above the gate, bow resting easy but ready. He caught my eye. I gave a small nod. He returned it without smiling. Trust, measured out in millimetres.

In the yard, a scouting party was rolling out. A battered minivan, once blue, now a patchwork of rust and taped-on armour. Someone had painted a crude symbol on the side in yellow. I raised a hand and gave them a wave. One of them leaned out the window and waved back, wide grin, like they were heading off on a school trip instead of into whatever waits beyond the walls. The gate groaned open just long enough to let them through, then sealed again.

Beyond the inner wall, tucked into a corner where the wind is kinder, sits the trade school. A generous name for a shelter built from scavenged scaffolding and stretched canvas. The ropes are well tied. That alone makes me feel better.

A small group waited underneath. The ones who didn’t pass the skill triage. No obvious trades, no tidy labels. Just people with hands, backs, and fear they’re trying not to show. A couple clutched mugs. One
was chewing on a bit of string like it might tell them what to do.

I stepped under the canvas, dropped the supply forms onto a crate, and clapped once.

“Right,” I said. “This is Fire 101.”

They focused immediately.

“Heat. Healing. Sterilization. Communication,” I paused, then added, “and arson.”

That last word rippled through them. A nervous laugh. A raised eyebrow. Good. Fire deserves respect.

I laid out the kit. Firesteel worn smooth, tinder bundles, clean cloth, a kettle blackened by a hundred boils. I talked about warmth and cooking, about sealing wounds and cleaning tools. About smoke signals and light at distance. About how fire can keep you alive, and how it will kill you just as easily if you get lazy.

By the end, their hands were steadier. Not confident. Not yet. But steadier. In this place, that counts as progress.

name: James
title: Patrol
contentHtml:
James walks around the castle checking on the day to day workings of everything. What he doesnt know how to run he makes sure there is someone who does.

When there hasnt been any sighting of the infected for a day or so he'll be seen without his helmet on but never without his configured cpap mask. Folks arent sure if its paranoia or some preempative measure but its clear he thinks either whats causing this is airborne or in time it will be.

Its not a new eden, nor is the castle a paradise. People are medically triaged, the 'useful' are prioritised over those who lack in skills and whilst it is a safe environment generally there is a scent of fear in the air over what the world has become as it is still early days in the outbreak.

In one of the ancillairy buildings is a table with a large map. Skipton itself is divided into districts with sightings of infected pinned. Resources are noted be they farms, forests, unpolluted rivers or even buildings that have not yet scavanged.

Every few hours there are teams going in and out. Some by foot and some by car using the limited reserves of fuel to scout surrounding areas, often willing to take whatever help they can.

A few other structures appear up as 'lean tos' against the ancient stone walls. Where once it was wood and thatch now there is PVC piping and canvas. Of these buildings are a trade school teaching those who fail the initial 'skill triage' some useful trades, a field hospital tending to scouts, soldiers and refugees alike and a scrap shop for hoarders alike to rummage through scavanged material to make things of use to the inhabitants of the castle

name: Cat
title: Silly pranks
contentHtml:
Dear diary,

Guess I'm back to journaling!? That therapist may have not been the greatest, but she was right about journaling. At least, it's worked in the past and I'll do anything at this point in time to ease the anxiety. Got to rationalise it all or something.

It started like any old Wednesday. Waking up for work, hurriedly getting ready and driving there only to arrive early. I opened the department, letting my computer boot up in the office as I opened the windows and boiled the kettle for my colleagues; my typical 'opening shift'. I eventually settled at my desk, letting my mouse drift onto the news tab I keep perpetually open in my browser for some absent scrolling and information gathering. After looking at the local stuff, I went into the country wide page, expecting to see some comments on PMQ's and updates on the various conflicts of the world but, dominating the screen was an article about 'April Fool's Day'. Of course, the date has passed me by in a haze of counting down until the next holiday and I chuckled to myself, opening the article. I only got a brief glimpse, glancing at phrases such as 'practical joke' and 'internet craze' before one of my colleagues came in and I resigned myself to office small talk until my first lesson.
Lunchtime came and went with little fanfare, sitting down to eat and check emails before being pulled away to sort out some of the exam technology that had broken. I'd get to my endless to do list eventually, the students were the priority and the admin could get done later. The article had slipped my mind in the blur of 1:1 sessions and note taking and emotional regulation, so when I arrived in the final class of the day, I couldn't stop myself from listening in when I heard the word "zombie" in a conversation between some of the teenagers. I can't remember what was exactly said, but it was something like this:
Student A: "... has been updating all day. They started off saying it was something local, but it seems to be spreading."
Student B: "Well of course! The secondary schools are all kicking out and the kids are all jumping in on it for the TikTok views."
Student A: "I don't think it's just kids though..."
Student C: "He's right, I got forwarded a video of a load of adults chasing people in a park."
Student B: "I bet it was for some sort of drama thing. Or maybe a film? These things can be from AI too. Was it forwarded from your Gran or something?"
Student C: "Oh shut up! It was one time and I..."

They were cut off by the teacher coming in and getting their attention. The register was taken, the content delivered and the conversation forgotten. My brain kept on turning over on what I knew. Surely the police would stop large groups from chasing individuals? That was harassment or something! I vowed to keep an eye out on the way home, especially if it appeared to be 'spreading'.
Driving home was uneventful, and I almost forgot the events of the day until after dinner when I checked my messages to see a few people checking in to make sure I was ok. I replied that all was well; I'm not the kind of person to advertise when I'm struggling or ask for help, and then check ins from multiple people made me do a double take. The responses seemed relieved, if not a little on edge, and, when I asked everyone what they were on about, they just sent me back the link to the news article. It seemed that this 'prank' was going on into the night, with people appearing to take it as an excuse to raid shops. Pietro messaged saying that their mum had seen someone smashing the window of Tesco as she drove out the car park, and had asked them to check on me, as I wasn't too far. I reassured both Pietro and their mum with a text that all was well, but kept the article open. Something felt off, and I didn't want to miss out on what the broadcasters said.

All evening, I've been on edge, thinking about people being stupid and taking pranks too far. Rationally and logically, I know it'll all blow over tonight, especially if it's some sort of prank, I just can't help but feel a little panicked though, like we're on the edge of something huge. Writing it all out makes it seem a little clearer, it's just some huge pop culture moment that is getting out of hand. I don't want it to be like lockdown, where it's not taken seriously until it's too late. Maybe I'll check the article again...

name: Charles
title: Fucking Mondays
contentHtml:
It's Monday, why does shit always go south on a fucking Monday? Stocked up the van with food, armour, camping supplies and my tools. 
Me and Evie have got the animals and made sure they were safe as I checked oil and pumped the tyres up with air.
 looking over my shoulders, trusty hickory handle estwing hammer in hand i was ready to spring like a steel coil clamped too hard in a vice. 

The ride to my work was a quick drive due how out of the way site was.
I grabbed as many jerry cans of diesel as I could pump from the bowser and smashed the lock of the storage containers, two small generators was all I could fit snug side by side in the back of the transit. 
The drive was silent and tense I'm keeping to the the country roads to avoid people. the fog is rolling in as a I get closer to Skipton, I've seen so much abandoned cattle and sheep on the way,
My phone vibrates in the cab cupholder.
"At the Castle. Gates are shut. Get here."

name: Eve
title: Home Sweet Castle
contentHtml:
We arrived at the castle with little fanfare other than the well-meaning threats. We let the lads go first under the guise of chivalry; mostly it was because I had the lorry in reverse, so if things did go south we could skedaddle out of there while the boys caused a distraction.

I wasn’t that worried, we had the text from James as an excuse to at least stay the night, but you always need an escape route, and overall I still had the bigger vehicle — a change from my little baby Kevin. But you’re more likely to survive the breakdown of society in a 4x4 than a hairdryer strapped to a roller skate.

After much posturing (Jordan) and much discussion with the trigger-happy crossbowman (Elliot), they opened the gate. I was surprised they let us keep our weapons, but was promptly distracted from that surprise by the wonderful sight of Morgana prowling over to inspect us. Oh, and James was looking down on us from the battlements, shouting in a stupid French accent, “Your mother was a hamster and your father smelt of elderberries.”

Things are looking up

name: James
title: Setting Up
contentHtml:
A few of the earlier reenactor arrivals had already made good headway on the interior. The old kitchen within the castle was reformed as its original purpose with the great hall acting as an administrative centre where details of refugees and their skill sets were noted.

The chapel had become an armoury. Farmer's shotguns stood beside crossbows as if a descendant meeting their ancestor.

Rudimentry defences had been set up along the base of the curtain walls with the occassional dead infected cadaver in front of the main gatehouse being burned periodically by the garrison.

What ground within the castle walls wasnt taken up by tents, sleeping spaces and storage became raised beds for vegetables and crops, a small corall in the corner already hosted some goats, cattle, geese and chickens.

I knew a fair few of those who had already setup inside. Cliffords mostly but generally reenactors of many colours. The blue and yellow checkered flag of the cliffords flew just above a familiar yellow and green.

I didnt have much time to go around outside of my armour. I had already been saved from an infected bite by my chunky gambeson.

Hearing the sound of multiple vehicles turn up i walked to the ramparts and looked down, another familiar colour of green and yellow. I scribble quickly on a notepad and hand it to one of the guards

"If any come in with these names, dont confiscate their weapons and let them through, they'll be using one of two sets of names. All others process as normal"

Its quite clear the list has a collection of 'real' names and 'larp' names.

"OPEN THE GATE"

with a loud creak and the sound of bolts sliding, those who have arrived can enter to be greeted by an all too familiar grey cat with white socks as James looks down with his helmet on

name: Cat
title: Time to Convoy
contentHtml:
I was driving in the woods when Eve's message came through. The location pin wasn't too far off; I could make it there within the hour. The boot was full of spare tools, wool and other odd supplies that altogether made a ramshackle bank of supplies. The woods were eerie as I unlocked the door to the Guide hut. I picked out what I could, squeezing tarps next to saucepans, unsure of what we'd be missing. The wind began to pickup, carrying with it sounds of movement. Increasing my speed, I packed what I could into the car, before driving away. I had to get to the others.

Driving in convoy, we found the service station, loading supplies into the transit like a well oiled machine. Everything fit together like a game of Tetris, with an air of chaos and disorganisation. We all squeezed together in the cab, agreeing to take turns in driving. Stopping at this stage is risky, especially as the van has made us a larger, well supplied target for other groups. The radio hums with static, discordant and busy. I watch as the miles tick by, trying to keep my hands busy with some knitting; surely we'll need some things to keep warm with? Keeping awake and aware is important, and I absent mindedly watch the scenery roll by as we drive towards the North.

I jump a little as someone's phone buzzes. I look down, we all get the same message from James. I think it may be the last update we get for a while...

"At the Castle. Gates are shut. Get here."

name: Elliot
title: Stocking Up
contentHtml:
I didn’t take the main roads today. Too exposed. Too many eyes. I moved through towns like a ghost, slipping in where I could, taking what mattered, leaving the rest to rot.

The pharmacy was first. Glass already smashed, shelves half-looted, that sharp chemical smell hanging in the air. I grabbed anything that looked useful. Painkillers, antibiotics, bandages, antiseptic. Stuff people will need if this goes on. Stuff I will need. I didn’t linger. Every second inside felt like tempting fate.

The library was worse, somehow. Quiet in a way that felt wrong. Pages scattered like leaves after a storm. I filled my bag with textbooks. Herbal medicine. Foraging. Survival manuals. Old stuff, written back when people expected the world to end every few generations. There’s comfort in that. Proof that someone’s been here before and made it through.

The museum nearly broke me. Not emotionally. Practically. I stood there staring at suits of armour behind glass, weapons mounted on the walls like trophies, and all I could think was how stupid it was that we ever stopped using what worked. Medieval plate, chainmail, gambesons. Blades, polearms, shields. I took what I could carry. Heavy. Awkward. Real. It felt ridiculous and completely necessary all at once.

I hit an electronics shop on the way out of town. Radios, walkie-talkies, batteries, chargers. Anything that still worked went in the boot. If we’re going to survive, we need to talk to each other. Silence gets you killed.

I met up with Eve, Rhi, and Cat at a service station just off the bypass. They were already busy. Fuel siphoned from dead cars into jerry cans. Rhi halfway inside a lorry cab, wires hanging out like veins. Eve keeping watch. Cat grinning like she’d always known it would come to this.

They got the engine going. Loud. Ugly. Beautiful.

I followed the lorry north, keeping my distance, watching it
carve a path through empty roads. Skipton rose out of the distance like something out of a storybook, stone walls and old bones standing stubborn against the end of everything.

We stopped at the gatehouse. No one said anything at first. Then we raised the banner. Yellow and green, quartered, catching the wind like it still mattered. Like we still mattered.

We called out together, voices echoing off the stone.

“Gregor! I mean—James!”

I held my hands up, away from my belt. I’ve never felt more exposed in my life. I’m standing in the shadow of 900 years of history, hoping my mate is actually inside and hasn't lost his mind.

name: Evie
title: Seeya Sheffield
contentHtml:
We had to pack up as much as we could to leave Sheffield. We heard from our friends that they were all heading to Skipton for safety.
Coco was pacing around, knowing something was wrong. I wish I could explain to her that home wasn't going to be home anymore. Pippin? Honestly, she was soundly sleeping next to the radiator... It felt cruel to wake her from her slumber and take her away from her home, but what else could we do?
I grabbed all the food we had that wouldn’t perish quickly. It would only last us a few weeks, maybe a couple of months at best, but it was better than nothing. Charles was gathering his tools to fix anything that needed it... or, in the worst case scenario, to use as weapons.
We loaded up the van with whatever essentials we could think of (medication, blankets, warm clothing, etc.) with the limited time we had. We’d heard the roads were going to get busy soon.
I placed Coco in the footwell on her dog bed and Pip in her carrier on the dashboard. Trying to keep them calm is heartbreaking. They're not stupid...now they could see for themselves that the world is no longer the same.
The ride is deafeningly silent. No longer are the days of laughing and singing along to Alice in Chains to pass the time. Everything feels dull and heavy.
We stopped at one point at Charlies work site to grab some bits, honestly I was too shaken up to even notice much around me, all I remember is I was told to stay in the van and don't open the door for any reason.
I can't stop shaking. The van feels stuffy, but I also can’t handle what would happen once we reached our destination.
I know Charlie won’t stay put for long. He’d want to go out and find more supplies as soon as he knew that me and the animals were safe. He hasn’t said anything, but I know he will, and I feel selfish for not wanting him to leave...

Both our phones vibrate.

It's James.

"At the Castle. Gates are shut. Get here."

name: Jordan
title: Skipton Castle
contentHtml:
We’re at the gates. Skipton is different. Everywhere else we’ve been has been loud - screaming, engines, that wet, tearing sound those things make. But here? It’s eerily still. There are abandoned cars littering the High Street, doors left wide open, suitcases spilled out onto the pavement, but no movement. The silence is worse than the noise.

I pulled the car up as close to the gatehouse as I could. The massive doors are shut tight. I switched off the engine and for a second, I just sat there, hands shaking on the steering wheel. Poppy is standing in the back, her nose pressed against the glass.

I got out. The air smells like woodsmoke and campfires.

I looked up, and nearly shit myself. The battlements were manned with people, but they weren't cheering. They were watching us like we were a threat. A surreal mix, some of them are in surplus military gear and high-vis vests, holding cricket bats wrapped in barbed wire or old hunting rifles. But others... others look like they’ve stepped out of a history book. I saw a guy in a full gambeson holding a pike that must have been five hundred years old.

There’s no trust left. You can feel it in the air - cold and hostile. To them, I’m just another desperate person who might be carrying the sickness. One of the blokes on the wall, wearing a riot helmet and holding a heavy-looking crossbow, leveled it at my chest.

"Stay there!" he shouted. His voice cracked. He’s terrified.

I held my hands up, away from my belt. I’ve never felt more exposed in my life. I’m standing in the shadow of 900 years of history, hoping my mate is actually inside and hasn't lost his mind.

"I'm looking for James!" I yelled back, trying to keep my voice from shaking. "Tell him Jordan is here. From the Crosslands!"

Nobody moved. The guy with the crossbow didn't lower it. I can hear Minty meowing in the back of the car, she’s fed up, and honestly, I’m right there with her. I just need them to open the bloody door.

name: Rhiannon
title: Time to go
contentHtml:
Leaving Romsey behind felt wrong. In the early morning light, the town was silent, abandoned in a way I’d never experienced before. The few people left, including Ben next door who had given me his van, we too stubborn to leave their homes.

I’d grabbed as much useful crap from Moles as I could, stocking up on clothes, hot water bottles, all the food they had. Even gardening tools; they’ll be useful for planting the seeds I’d got. I’d also grabbed the cavalry saber and the truncheon from home, along with all of my camping equipment, and every warm thing I could find.  I'm just grateful that when this all started I stockpiled my insulin, it'll at least last me a while, as long as I do my best to ration it along with the rest of my medications.

Map on the seat next to me, I started out towards the motorway, heading to the distribution centre where I planned to meet up with Eve and Cat; our phones were still working for now. The roads were deserted; in the movies you always see them packed with the panicked masses, but reality is much quieter. The world didn’t end with a bang, it just feels like it went to sleep.

I took a risk detouring to the office, but I know there are useful supplied there; the bonus of the garaged being full of engineer’s equipment and heaters. If we can get a generator set up, those radiators will be a godsend come winter. I can’t risk going any further into Winchester, especially with the hospital nearby, so this is my last stop until I met the others.

At the distribution centre, I get started siphoning all the fuel I can, we’ll need as much as possible for the future. There’s a garage next door with a small shop, so I take the wagon over there to grab everything I can, food, drinks, toiletries, the lot. As I hear another vehicle approaching, my phone vibrated in my pocket. 

Message from James - “At the Castle. Gates are shut. Get here.”

I guess it’s time to go

name: Jordan
title: Maybe I'll be back, York
contentHtml:
We had to leave York. It wasn't a choice. Those people, or whatever they are, are everywhere. It’s not like they’re dead; they’re just... wrong. Violent.

The drive towards Skipton is a nightmare. I’m trying to keep us on the back roads, avoiding anywhere too busy.

My brain is constantly running through lists: fuel, water, weapons, safety. I’m trying to keep Jenni calm, but honestly, I'm about to have a meltdown. She spent the night in the car hand-sewing clothes together to make them thicker.

Poppy is sitting in the back, staring out the window. She saw one of them run across the road and she didn't bark, she just let out this low, vibrating growl I’ve never heard from her before. 

It’s like she knows things have changed. Minty is in her carrier, hissed out. I feel like a bastard for putting them through this, but I couldn't leave them behind.

James sent a text - last one that came through. 

“At the Castle. Gates are shut. Get here.”

name: Eve
title: Time to hijack a lorry!!
contentHtml:
We left Bordon just after dawn. The town was quiet in the way a room is quiet after a party — cups still out, doors open, nobody home. I went back to the flat once for the important things: weapons, first aid, camping gear, and the cat carrier containing Bemish and Schrödinger, who both felt the need to express their feelings about this situation loudly and at length. They did not approve. They have never approved of anything.

We picked up Cat first, who had a backpack, a crowbar, and a very strong opinion about not being eaten by anything today. Rhiannon was further north at a service station, siphoning diesel with the casual competence of someone who had clearly been waiting her whole life for societal collapse. I didn’t ask questions. I just held the funnel.

The Transit van was sitting behind a distribution centre, white paint scuffed, logo half peeled, keys still in it like the universe wanted us to take the hint.

We loaded everything that wasn’t nailed down — food, water, medical supplies, blankets, batteries, pet food, and enough tins to start our own very depressing shop. The back of the van now smells like diesel, peaches, and fear. It’s not an improvement, but it’s not terrible.

The cab is full of practical nonsense. Knives wrapped in tea towels. An axe wedged behind the seat. Firelighters rattling every time we hit a bump. I keep patting things like I’m checking they’re still real. I hope the skills I taught so casually come back to me when they matter. Shelter. Fire. Keeping people busy so they don’t panic. I’m trying to believe that includes preparing for the end of the world.

The engine hums. The world feels hollow. Bemish is asleep. Schrödinger is staring out the window like he’s judging my lane discipline.

James sent a text. Last one that came through.

"At the Castle. Gates are shut. Get here"

name: Elliot
title: A full car
contentHtml:
We had to get out early, before the roads filled with whatever passes for traffic now. The motorways were empty in that unsettling way, long grey ribbons stretching ahead with no headlights coming the other way. Overhead signs flicked past like warnings meant for someone else. Every slip road felt like a gamble.

The back of the car is crammed to the roof with kit from the scout hut. Tents, roll mats, mess tins, coils of rope, boxes of half-used fuel tabs. Things that once smelled of damp weekends and burnt sausages now feel like treasure. I broke the lock myself. Told myself I would come back and make it right. I don’t believe that lie, but it helped me turn the key.

I keep replaying the plan in my head because it’s the only thing holding me together. Get to Skipton. The old castle. Group up. Make a plan that’s bigger than just surviving the next mile. I say it silently like a mantra as the white lines tick by.

The passenger seat is a mess of sharp, practical comfort. Axes stacked awkwardly, knives wrapped in cloth, firelighting kits rattling every time I brake. I pat them without thinking, the way you check your pockets for keys. I hope the skills I taught so casually come back to me when it matters. Shelter, fire, keeping people busy so they don’t panic. I’ve always told the kids that preparation is kindness. I’m trying to believe it now.

Nobody’s talking much. The car hums, the world feels hollow, and I don’t know what waits at the end of the road. I just know we have to keep moving.

James sent a text. Last one that came through.

“At the Castle. Gates are shut. Get here.”

name: James
title: Got to get to the castle
contentHtml:
The van rattles, Leeds hadnt been hit by the outbreak yet but that didnt stop the looting.
"Billhooks, halbards, falchions, as much armour as i could grab"

I took a lengthy detour north of bradford, frantically calling my reenactment mates first to meet at the castle but each call sapped the battery.

Avoiding the M62 i got to rawtenstall to grab biffy who loaded the van with their fabrics and anything else useful from my own house; blankets, jerky, weapons, armour, we even lobbed the black fluff Macey onto the middle seat.

By the time we got to Skipton a small gaggle of the Cliffords were already there reinforcing the gatehouse and dragging in supplies and other survivors. There werent many as the bulk of the town had foolishly fled to the cities thinking they were safer there.

Breathe... breathe.... breathe. I was running the scenario so many times in my head but when push comes to shove it doesnt prepare you for the reality.

The gates were locked and guards were posted on the walls with polearms and bows, we made a start on organising peoples skills and where they would bunk or camp.

It was April fortunately which meant we could make a start on growing crops and dealing with long term issues now without worrying about a winter cold snap. We stationed a lookout atop the nearby Trinity Church, where once fire wardens stood in the war now someone stands looking for survivors or watching for the infected.

As the night began to set, that last thing i feared turned up on my phone: "1%"

Mulling it over i sent out one last message before the phone died:

"At the Castle. Gates are shut. Get here"
